content: I'm currently using Django 1.3 and noticed it includes a collectstatic command to gather static files into STATIC_ROOT. I also have some additional global files that need to be served using STATICFILES_DIR. Is it possible for me to configure both to use the same directory?

In Django 1.3, the `collectstatic` command is used to gather all static files from your apps and any additional locations specified in `STATICFILES_DIRS` into the directory specified by `STATIC_ROOT`. However, it's important to note that `STATIC_ROOT` is meant to be a single directory where all static files are collected for deployment, and it should not overlap with any of the directories listed in `STATICFILES_DIRS`.

If you try to set `STATICFILES_DIRS` to include `STATIC_ROOT`, you might run into issues where files are copied on top of each other, or you could create a loop where the command keeps copying files back and forth.

The recommended approach is to ensure that `STATICFILES_DIRS` includes all the directories where your static files are located, excluding `STATIC_ROOT`. These directories can contain your global files as well. When you run `collectstatic`, it will gather all these files into `STATIC_ROOT`, which you can then use for serving static files in production.

Here's an example configuration:

```python
# settings.py

# Directory where collectstatic will gather all static files
STATIC_ROOT = '/path/to/static_root/'

# List of directories where Django will search for additional static files
STATICFILES_DIRS = [
    '/path/to/your/global/static/files/',
    '/another/path/to/static/files/',
    # Add more directories as needed
]
```

After setting this up, you can run the `collectstatic` command to gather all static files into `STATIC_ROOT`:

```bash
python manage.py collectstatic
```

This way, you can manage your additional global files efficiently without causing any configuration issues.
